content.description: Climb up the nice friction slab on perfect crystals and edges.
content.location:
Right of the

Warm-up Dihedral

, start just right of center slab trending slightly left up a line of good crystals and edges. Quite a few low angle, mentally engaging lines can be contrived on the face.

content.description: Jam the dihedral handcrack using slab feet to a thoughtful topout.
content.location:
This ascends the obvious, right-facing corner right of

Pretend There's Rope

.

content.description: Sit start, and climb the crack out and over the exposure.
content.protection: A pad would protect the first butt dragger moves, then you are committed over the steep boulder jumble below. Falling would probably cause serious injury.
content.location:
Scramble into the small corridor south of

Mighty Bite

. It's on a ledge perched on the left (east) rock.

content.description: Start on a jug under the lip. Reach to a thin gaston flake. Use crystals and pressing power to mantel and establish yourself on the slab, and top out.
content.location:
It is part of The Stacks proper. The easiest way is to hike to The Saddle and go past

Andrew's Crack

. Head southwest of

Warm-up Slab

and around the adjacent boulder. This is behind

Holy Moley

, just to the west.

content.description: Begin underneath the crack inside the small hunter's den. Jam and pull into the roof, and follow the crack to the top. Climb out either side of the "den".
content.location:
Head southeast from

Mossy The Snowman

, and locate this floating egg split by a crack. The boulder has been worked into a small hut of sorts, I assume for hunting. It is best to leave things as found, and keep an eye out for hunting in the area.

content.description: Sit start at unique blocky compression holds. Climb up through thin and technical rock utilizing the right sloping arete, and carefully top out.
content.protection: Pads and a spotter. The landing is good, but it drops away to the right of the problem.
content.location:
This is a few feet right of

Go Dumb

.

content.description: Yet another lowball, this has superb moves and technical aspects. SDS compressing with your hands as wide and low as possible. Move into the jug, and carefully sequence a strenuous mantel on thin and cryptic holds. This is techy and powerful.
content.location: Head south from the Craftmatic Boulder to find this small freestander.

content.description: Sit start far right on very low crystals. Hand traverse, surf all the way left on the jug rail, and top out. This is painful.
content.location:
It is just behind

The Alex-izer

on the east face.

content.description: Start on the left-facing jug/flake. Climb directly up through thin face crimps to a terrifying, hollow flake up high. Delicately mantel the flake, and top out. We've seen it hold about 200lbs....
content.protection: Pads and a spotter. The flake is up pretty dang high and looks like it would result in serious injury if it detached while one was manteling/standing on top of it. The FAist assumed it had been done and the line was solid, hence the name as we proceeded to send.
content.location:
It is just right of

Andrew's Crack

in the small corridor.

content.description: Start sitting with wide reached arms to a right hand sidepull and left hand sloper. Climb straight up. I gave it an extra star for the fun exposure of standing on top!
content.location:
Just east of

Daydreamer

, there are three boulders stacked that resemble a snowman. This climbs the northwest faces. There is an easy downclimb off the other side.

content.description: This climbs the aesthetic, floating block without using the adjacent boulder it's leaning on. Start low and left with your left hand on the edge at the lip and a small pinch block under the roof for your right hand. Climb rightward until you can get a toe on at the lip, then rock over to a long reach to a small sharp pinch. Lock off, and reach to the top for better holds.
content.protection: Pads and a spotter for the slightly downhill landing.
content.location:
It is at the top of the hill that comprises The Stacks area just uphill from

The Book Traverse

.

content.description: Sit start using large crystal hand holds resembling sharp incisors. Climb up the face on big but crumbly holds.
content.location:
It is just right of

Happy Birthday

in the small corral of rock.

content.description: Start by reaching to good holds on the arete above head height. Pull up, establish yourself on the slab left of the arete, and try not to stain it brown on your way to the top. Are you awake now?
content.protection: Pads and a spotter. YGD if you pitch from the upper slab.
content.location:
It is essentially on top of The Stacks area. The easiest way is to hike to The Saddle and go past

Andrew's Crack

corridor. It is just southwest of

Warm-up Slab

on the adjacent boulder at the far left (south) end. Some easy scrambling is required.

content.description: Start low on layback edges, and paste your feet on underneath. Move through sharp holds, and surmount the hanging bulge. All adjacent rock is considered 'off'.
content.protection: A pad for the sharp block in the landing.
content.location:
It is on the back of the small, diagonal, handcrack egg that's sandwiched between two boulders behind

The Book Traverse

to the southeast. As most, this gem is hidden. The photos and some exploring should help.

content.description: Gain the floating block by climbing the slab rock below. Heel hook and crimp straight up the bulge utilizing crumbly but good holds right where you need them to a high topout. The FA was done in approach shoes, sans pads and spotters. There are some very suspect crimps, but this is a VERY worthy ascent!
content.protection: Pads and spotters are a good idea. It is tall with some questionable rock throughout.
content.location:
Head left (west) from

Ace's Arete

, and you'll find a small corral with this and

The Incisor

.

content.description: Sit start in the small cave on a jug. Climb up through face moves, a finger crack, and a layback to top out.
content.location:
At the left end of a small corridor of boulders left (east) of

The Alex-izer

a small, left-facing cave/cleft is the start.

content.description:
Start as for

Daydreamer

, but traverse right under the upper boulder until you reach a crack above that will bring you to the top. It may be a good idea to walk around the back of the boulder to suss the downclimb/small jump down before you climb this.
content.location:
See the description and photo for

Daydreamer

.

content.description: Doozy is a great, moderate lowball. SDS with compressing hands low and wide on the left edge and right sloping arete. Move into the jug, and crank up and right. Establish yourself on the surprisingly thin but short slab, and top out.
content.location:
It is opposite of

Craftmatic

on the same boulder.

content.description: Reach from the small slab to a decent hold on the lip over the roof. Lockoff on some small crystals, get a high foot, and mantel. It is a supremely thin and cerebral problem. It may be a good idea to walk around the back of the boulder to suss the downclimb/small jump down before you climb this.
content.protection: Pads and spotters. It's a tall problem, and the crux is a bit high over several boulders in the landing. It's manageable overall.
content.location:
East of

Full Retard

and just west of

Mossy The Snowman

, this is on a large, round block resting on a small slabby "stalk" and climbs the east face.

content.description: SDS with a left hand sidepull and your right hand on the big, flat edge. Lock a heel hook, and surf right to a jug. Roll onto the ledge, and begin to lose style points through the awkward finish. This was the first problem climbed here.
content.location: The top of the saddle is a large flat area. This small block sits on the left (north) end of this area, before the talus starts.

content.description: Start far left, and traverse the horizontal crack, topping out at a large edge and feature on the right.
content.location:
Behind and uphill from

Mossy The Snowman

and

Daydreamer

, this is in the highest area within The Stacks.

content.description: Climb the slab behind the big tree on nubbins and edges utilizing the arete out right if desired.
content.protection: Pads. The tree has your back....
content.location:
Around the corner south of

Ace's Arete

, it's behind the tree which begins the left edge of a "corridor" of boulders.

content.description: Climb the obvious hand jam crack with an exciting exit. This is tall and classic, do it!
content.protection: Pads and spotters. It is best to be really solid on this one. Falling from the last moves and landing in the small corral of boulders couldn't possibly end well.
content.location:
It is just right of

Backscratcher

in the small corridor area.

content.description: Start sitting as far right as possible. Traverse the interesting lip using good pockets, crystals, and heel hooks to the obvious jug ledge on the left and pull over top.
content.location:
It is on the low and long block, just before

The Incisor

.

content.description: Begin standing with a low, left hand sidepull on the arete and a hard-to-find, painful crystal crimp high and right. Get your feet on, and head up and left through a jug and a grovelly topout through the mossy trough.
content.location:
It is just south of

Smells Like Coffee

.
